title: Are there any known real numbers that we only know how to express in terms of complex numbers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. The bane of the sixteenth century mathematicians who solved the cubic equation is called casus irreducibilis, the irreducible case. There’s always a real solution to a cubic equation with integer coefficients. The irreducible case occurs when those real solutions are only expressible as the sum of two complex numbers. Of course that only applies to expressing the number using integers, the four arithmetic operations and root taking. There are other ways we can express these numbers, for example by saying “the root of <equation> near x=<approximation>.” Trig affords many examples, for example [math]\cos 20^\circ.[/math] That’s of course one third of sixty degrees. DeMoivre offers the complex expression: [math](\cos 20^\circ + i \sin 20^\circ)^3 = \cos 60^\circ + i \sin 60^\circ[/math] [math]\cos 20^\circ = \textrm{Re} \left( \sqrt[3]{ \cos 60^\circ + i \sin 60^\circ} \right)[/math] Since the real part is half the sum of a number and its conjugate, we get [math]\cos 20^\circ = \frac 1 2 \left( \sqrt[3]{ \cos 60^\circ + i \sin 60^\circ}+\sqrt[3]{ \cos 60^\circ - i \sin 60^\circ}\right)[/math] [math]\cos 20^\circ = \frac 1 2 \left( \sqrt[3]{ \frac 1 2(1 + i\sqrt{3}) }+\sqrt[3]{ \frac 1 2(1-i\sqrt{3}) }\right)[/math] [math]\cos 20^\circ = \frac 1 {4} \left( \sqrt[3]{ 4 + 4i\sqrt{3}}+\sqrt[3]{ 4-4i\sqrt{3} }\right)[/math] That’s a real number expressed in terms of the cube roots of a couple of complex numbers. The cube roots aren’t independent; to get the real solution we need a conjugate pair of cube roots. It’s actually a case of casus irreducibilis; there’s no expression consisting of integers, the four operations and real root taking which will express the same number. Let’s look at the irreducible cubic equation. We know [math]\cos 60^\circ = \frac 1 2 [/math] and that the triple angle formula is [math]\cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos ^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta[/math] So [math]x=\cos 20^\circ[/math] satisfies [math]\frac 1 2 = 4 x^3 - 3x[/math] [math]8x^3 - 6x - 1 = 0[/math] That’s a depressed cubic, no [math]x^2[/math] term. There’s a depressed cubic formula that’s pretty straightforward; let’s give it a try: [math]x^3 + 3px = 2q [/math] has solutions [math]x= \sqrt[3] { q + \sqrt{p^3+q^2} } + \sqrt[3] { q - \sqrt{p^3+q^2} } [/math] [math] x^3 - \frac 3 4 x = \frac 1 8[/math] We have [math]p=-1/4, q=1/16, p^3+q^2=-3/256, \sqrt{p^3+q^2}=\frac {\sqrt{3}}{16} i[/math] [math]x= \sqrt[3] { \frac 1 {16}+ \frac {\sqrt{3}}{16} i } + \sqrt[3] { \frac 1 {16}-\frac {\sqrt{3}}{16} i  } [/math] [math]x= \frac 1 {4} \left( \sqrt[3] { 4+ 4i\sqrt{3} } + \sqrt[3] { 4 - 4i\sqrt{3}} \right) [/math] We get the same expression as before, involving complex numbers. There’s no way to express [math]\cos 20^\circ[/math] in an expression of integers composed via the four arithmetic operations and real root taking.

My favorite is the following. The cubic can be solved by radicals alone, and the quartic can also be solved as either a cubic-and-linear or quadratic-and-quadratic, while (at least some) quintics exist that cannot be expressed by radicals alone. All well and good. Now all angle trisections reduce to a particular cubic. One of the earliest realizations that you cannot trisect a general angle with a compass and a straight edge is associated with the fact that you cannot trisect the 60-degree angle (or pi/3 radians). If you work out the cubic, with Theta=(pi/3), “solving” the trisection cubic brings you back to the cube-root of exp(i Theta), as an irreducible form. The only “answer” yout get is that it is exp(i Theta/3) = exp( i pi/9), but you cannot get separate expressions out for cos(pi/9) or sin(pi/9) individually, even though both are fine “real numbers”.
